channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia’s Draft Sends Barely Trained Men to War in Ukraine
item.description: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: Strikes Hit Staging Ground for Troops in Russia’s Border Region
item.description: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A government building in the Russian-controlled city of Donetsk that was heavily damaged in an attack on Sunday.

item.title: Jill Biden Ramps Up Visits to Democratic Midterm Campaigns
item.description: Requests for the first lady, who is also the president’s most popular surrogate, are piling up ahead of the midterm elections. Her visits can deliver a morale boost and a fund-raising opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Jill Biden, center, appeared at a rally for Representative Val B. Demings, second from left, and Charlie Crist, second from right, on Saturday as part of a bustling weekend of events.

item.title: Warnock Hammers Walker in Senate Debate, Gesturing to an Empty Lectern
item.description: Herschel Walker did not join the debate, but Senator Raphael Warnock opted for direct attacks over the veiled criticisms he has used for most of his campaign.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:description: The Libertarian candidate for Senate in Georgia, Chase Oliver, left, and Senator Raphael Warnock, the Democratic incumbent, debated alongside an empty lectern representing Herschel Walker, the Republican, on Sunday in Atlanta.

item.title: Kari Lake Won’t Pledge to Accept Election Results, and More News From the Sunday Shows
item.description: “I’m going to win the election, and I will accept that result,” Kari Lake, a candidate for governor of Arizona, said on CNN. Evan McMullin said on NBC that he would never caucus with either party.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kari Lake, a candidate for governor of Arizona, in Phoenix. In an interview on CNN, she was asked if she would accept an election loss. “I’m going to win the election, and I will accept that result,” she said.

item.title: British Pound and Bond Prices Rise as New Chancellor Accelerates Tax Plans
item.description: Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s new top finance official, said he would bring forward by two weeks measures to “support fiscal sustainability.”
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Bank of England, in London. The central bank said Monday it had measures in place to support liquidity in the markets.

item.title: Iran’s Loyal Security Forces Protect Ruling System That Protesters Want to Topple
item.description: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Revolutionary Guards, a force with hundreds of thousands of members, is separate from the national army and is charged specifically with defending the ruling system.

item.title: China’s Leader Xi Hails His Rule as He Prepares to Expand Power
item.description: Xi Jinping is expected to secure a third term as leader during a pivotal meeting of the Communist Party, extending his authoritarian rule over the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher, Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China on Sunday at the opening ceremony of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Neymar, Barcelona and the Brazilian Who Wants His Money
item.description: A Brazilian supermarket magnate saw promise in the soccer star long before he became a household name. Now, believing he was cheated, he’s going to court for the payday that never arrived.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja

item.title: How to Stay Safe From Covid This Holiday Season
item.description: As our third pandemic winter approaches, you can mitigate risk without missing out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Macron the Disrupter Seeks Direction
item.description: He wants to lead a united Europe to independence. But the world has changed on him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations General Assembly last month.

item.title: Tens of Thousands March in Paris to Protest Rising Living Costs
item.description: The demonstration occurred on the heels of strikes at oil refineries, adding to a tense political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: A Posthumous Memoir Reveals Paul Newman in His Own Words
item.description: Compiled from interviews he gave to a close friend, “The Extraordinary Life of an Ordinary Man” sheds light on the self-doubt of the seemingly imperturbable Hollywood star.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.category: The Extraordinary Life of an Ordinary Man: A Memoir (Book)
item.media:description: “I am certain that nobody can always be responsible for what other people are,” Paul Newman says in a posthumous memoir surprising for its candor and vulnerability. “You can only be responsible for who you are.”

item.title: Stay Warm This Fall With Butternut Squash Lasagna
item.description: A pasta pie becomes a seasonal reverie for the senses.
item.dc:creator: Yotam Ottolenghi
item.media:credit: Chris Simpson for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Sophia Pappas.

item.title: Why Herschel Walker May Win
item.description: His performance in the Georgia Senate debate on Friday is a warning to Democrats who’ve found hope in the blunders of Republican candidates.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Putin’s Desperate Measures Won’t Get Him What He Wants
item.description: None of the Kremlin’s recent gambits are likely to change the battlefield dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Dara Massicot

item.title: Wait, Who Did You Say Is Middle-Aged?
item.description: Boomers didn’t appreciate getting long in the tooth. But as a Gen Xer, I have to assume it’s worse for us.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: We Should Try to Prevent Another Alex Jones
item.description: Even a billion-dollar verdict won’t stop the lies.
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Tufekci
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones outside the courthouse in Waterbury, Conn., in September.

item.title: Three Things Americans Should Learn From Xi’s China
item.description: The tactics he has used to maintain power may end up weakening his country in the end.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: Same-Sex Marriage Is a Religious Freedom
item.description: If the law allows same-sex couples to be treated differently from other couples, then our religious freedom to be married is not complete.
item.dc:creator: Steven Paulikas
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

item.title: How to Fight Back Against the Inhumanity of Modern Work
item.description: Digital technology has transformed work, often for the worse. Here are some solutions.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy

item.title: The Stacey Abrams Playbook
item.description: The Democratic candidate for governor looks back on her organizing efforts in 2020, which helped turn Georgia blue. Will her strategy work against the incumbent governor Brian Kemp?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team

item.title: How to Spend a Day in Red Hook
item.description: October can feel like the last hurrah for outdoor life. Make the most of it by eating along the Brooklyn waterfront.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Valentino special, with fried eggplant, provolone and peppers, at Defonte’s Sandwich Shop.

item.title: What Are Your Holiday Shopping Plans? We Want to Know.
item.description: Tell us about deals, budgets, wish lists and game plans for this holiday season, which promises to be challenging for retailers and customers alike.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Retailers have a lot riding on this year’s holiday season.

item.title: As Fox and News Corp Weigh Merger, an Activist Has Its Own Vision
item.description: Irenic Capital Management, which has a $150 million stake in News Corp, wants the company to split up its media and real estate listings businesses.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of News Corp and Fox, has proposed a merger of the two companies.

item.title: Discovery of Bodies in Oklahoma River Deepens Mystery of 4 Missing Friends
item.description: It was unknown whether the bodies were those of the four missing men, who were last heard from on Oct. 9, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

item.title: ALDS: Yankees Even Series With Game 4 Win Over Cleveland Guardians
item.description: Once again the Yankees took an early lead on the road, but this time it held up, forcing a decisive Game 5 on Monday in New York.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gerrit Cole allowed two runs on six hits in seven innings of work in Sunday’s Game 4 against the Cleveland Guardians. He struck out eight and walked one.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Katharine Briggs and Isabel Myers, Creators of a Personality Test
item.description: Mother and daughter, they developed the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, which has helped millions of people discover if they are introverts or extroverts or thinkers or feelers.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Rifkin and Benedict Carey
item.category: The Personality Brokers: The Strange History of Myers-Briggs and the Birth of Personality Testing (Book)

item.title: 4 Ways to Boost Your Immune System Ahead of Cold and Flu Season
item.description: Here are four things immunologists and other health experts say you can do.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo

item.title: Is Matcha Good for You?
item.description: The brightly colored powdered green tea has become popular among health-conscious consumers. Does it have any nutritional benefits?
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Vuity Review: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
item.description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vuity, eyedrops that can help people see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market in December.

item.title: Yes, Burt Bacharach Wrote That. And You Can Dance to It.
item.description: Mark Morris’s “The Look of Love” is set to Bacharach songs. “People are always saying, ‘Oh my God, he wrote that?’ That’s why I’m doing it,” Morris said.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Morris company dancers rehearsing “The Look of Love” at his studios in Brooklyn.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
